raw_text:
French boss to leave EADS
 
 The French co-head of European defence and aerospace group EADS Philippe Camus is to leave his post.
 
 Mr Camus said in a statement that he has accepted the invitation to return full-time to the Lagardere group, which owns 30% of EADS. "I will give up my role as soon as the board of directors asks me to do so," he said. Airbus head Noel Forgeard is now set to replace Mr Camus, bringing the company's power struggle to an end. Fighting between Mr Camus and Mr Forgeard has hit the headlines in France and analysts feared that this fighting could destabilise the defence and aerospace group. French finance minister Herve Gaymard is on record as saying that he "deplored" the infighting at the company. The company should now be able put this dispute behind it, with the departure of Mr Camus and with the clear support given to Mr Forgeard by the Lagardere group, the main French shareholder of EADS. The other main shareholders of EADS are the French government (15%) , who also support Mr Forgeard, and Germany's DaimlerChrysler (30%). Rainer Hertrich, the German co-head of EADS will also step down when his contract expires next year.
 
 Mr Camus recently came under pressure as it became clear that the A380 superjumbo was running over budget. EADS - Airbus' majority owner - admitted earlier this week that the project was running 1.45bn euros (£1bn; $1.9bn) over budget. But Mr Forgeard has denied this, telling French media that there is no current overrun in the budget. "But for the sake of transparency, we told our shareholders last week that if we look at the forecast for total costs of the project up to 2010, there is a risk that we will go over by around 10%, which is about 1bn euros (£686m; $1.32bn)," he told France's LCI Television. Due to enter service in 2006, the A380 will replace the Boeing 747 jumbo as the world's biggest passenger aircraft.
llama3.2:1b: French co-head Philippe Camus of EADS is leaving his post to return full-time to Lagardere, a French company that owns 30% of EADS.
Airbus head Noel Forgeard will replace him, bringing an end to power struggles within the group.
The departure has sparked concerns about the defense and aerospace company's ability to manage costs.

Noel Forgeard is replacing him as the new co-head.
The power struggle between Camus and Forgeard caused concerns about EADS' stability.
The company will now move forward without this conflict.
The A380 superjumbo project is running over budget but there are no current overrun issues, according to Airbus.

The company faces a financial crisis and may have to declare bankruptcy if there are any further delays in the project, which was originally due for completion by 2013.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The French boss Philippe Camus is leaving his post as EADS co-head of the European defence and aerospace group, with Noel Forgeard replacing him to take over.
The A380 superjumbo project faced a $1.45 billion budget overrun, but Forgeard denied it, stating transparency regarding potential overruns.

Hertrich, the German co-head, will also leave his role next year upon contract expiration.
tinyllama:1.1b: The French company Airbus has announced that its co-head Philippe Camus will leave his post at EADS, formerly known as European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company, by October, following the departure of two other executives.
The departure of Mr Camus, along with Lagarde Re Group co-head Noel Forgeard, was seen as a watershed moment for the power struggle within Airbus's power structure.
After years of infighting, the company should now be able to put this dispute behind it, with support from its main shareholders including the French government and DaimlerChrysler.
However, Rainer Hertrich, co-head of EADS, will also step down when his contract expires next year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The French boss of EADS has left his position, following an investigation into a project that exceeded its budget by over £1bn (approximately $1.9bn).
In addition to this, Airbus, the group's major shareholder, admitted that the A380 superjumbo was running over budget at the time of the disclosure.
The company has faced several scandals in recent years, with some analysts fearing it could face more trouble if these issues are not resolved.

The A380 superjumbo project is running over budget but Mr. Forgeford denied this and said they are currently on track to meet their cost estimates.

The departure of Mr Camus came amidst reports that the A380 superjumbo project was running over budget, but both he and his replacement deny this claim.

Earlier this week, EADS admitted that the A380 superjumbo project was running over budget; however, Forgeard denied this claim, stating there is no current overrun in the budget.
